subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Paul's keyboard proposal (withdrawn)
msgSnippet: I think we are making progress.  I am uploading my spreadsheet with Benct s amendment together with a minor amendment to my own proposal. I agree with Benct
messageBody:
I think we are making progress.  I am uploading my spreadsheet with Benct's amendment together with a minor amendment to my own proposal.

I agree with Benct that we should start from Senior QS in order to make the best assignment possible, though personally I am not quite so worried about the half letters as they are really not so important.  The use of these letters is largely a matter of choice.  They will never be mandatory. 

I would like to see more emphasis on the ligatures though I am happy that they can be made to work using kerning and joining as suggested in an earlier post.  Having had a bit of experience in typing with Anthony's Junior Text Tool which uses multiple keystrokes to form certain letters I would be more than happy to see this transferred into the new standard for the forming of ligatures.

Lets see if we can make further progress on the remaining disagreement letters then only the substantial agreement letters are left.

Happy New Year to you all

Moira

On 04/01/2008, Ted Larson Freeman < freeman@...> wrote:

I only have time for a brief reply this morning. I'll remove QS-Up and
BPJ1 from the spreadsheet and swap #15 and alternate #36 in BPJ2. I'll
make these changes on Sunday, just in case anyone pipes up in support
of either QS-Up or BPJ1 in the meantime. I'll also post some longer
examples of transliteration using each proposal.

The main reason I wanted to limit the scope of discussion at this
point is that I began with a pessimistic view of our chances of
reaching agreement even for this set of the free graphemes. Also I
worried that including Senior QS opens up several cans of worms
regarding proposed half-letters that are not in the QM, etc. If we
limit ourselves to the half-letters in the QM, and ignore other
subtleties of Senior QS, then it's fine with me to include them now.
(I do personally feel that, in general, having good assignments for
the half-letters is less important than having good assignments for
the 46 full letters.) What do other people think?

This native speaker likes your idea of assigning J to #14, freeing up
Z for assignment to half-#12. This was next on my list for discussion.
First I want to see if we can reach agreement on #21 and
alternate-#23.

I find the assignment of B to #37 to be the weakest in BPJ2. I'd like
to discuss several of the consonant assignments first, though.

Ted



On Jan 4, 2008 5:04 AM, Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> On 2.1.2008 Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> > I envision a two-step process. First, let's set the
> > standard for Junior QS. The 46 letters under current
> > discussion form a complete catalog of the individual
> > graphemes of the Read Alphabet. Designing glyphs for
> > this set is the first step in QS font development. (And
> > yes, technically this set includes letters from Senior
> > QS, but as I've said before I consider these letters
> > essential members of the alphabet that should be
> > included at this stage.)
> >
> > The schedule I've proposed is that we spend January
> > debating and refining the proposals, and February voting.
> > Once we've succeeded in setting this standard, we can move
> > on to Senior QS.
> >
> > Naturally one can plan ahead, as you've done in your
> > proposals. But please, it's going to be difficult enough
> > to set this standard. Let's not get ahead of ourselves.
>
> To design an ASCII transcription of any script which is not
> isomorphic with the 26-letter, two-case Roman alphabet --
> and I've been doing that a couple of times, for Devanagari,
> Tibetan, Avestan, IPA and most recently QS -- is a lot like
> solving Rubik's cube, in that all pairings you make between
> characters of the two sets make other pairings possible or
> impossible. So rather than getting ahead of ourselves we'd
> spare ourselves trouble at a later time by considering all
> of Senior QS from the outset.
>
> Suppose we had decided that we need to consider only Junior
> QS, excluding both alternate forms of #23 and #36 and half-
> letters we would cheerfully have mapped {N} to #21 and not
> even reflected that it is better to map it to alternate #23
> and that {G} is a reasonable mapping for #21. In the same
> way, if we don't consider the entire character set of Senior
> QS from the outset we must map what we left out -- the half-
> letters -- to the rubble left over from the first round of
> mappings. We would e.g. totally miss that {J} is a
> reasonable mapping for #14, leaving us free to map {Z} to
> half-z (#12.5), totally analogous to the case with {G} for
> #21 and {N} for alternate #23 (#23.2). Likewise if I had not
> considered the half-letters from the outset I would have
> found {H} with the memory cue "How" a jolly good mapping for
> #37, disregarding that {B} is a reasonable mapping on the
> grounds that
>
> - the memory cue "Bout" consists of the letter _B_ plus
> the name Read gave to this letter, - _B_ in TO stands
> for a labial sound /b/ and #37 may be considered to end
> in another labial sound /w/,
> - it recalls the Greek ligature for the digraph OU,
> which in turn recalls the normal spelling for #37 in
> English TO.
> - it leaves {H} free to be mapped to half-h (#19.5), for
> which one otherwise would have been forced to choose
> between mappings that were all essentially
> unsatisfactory.
>
> Naturally the experience of coming up with half-letter
> mappings for QS- SAMPA was helpful in coming to the
> conclusion that the full Senior QS including the half-
> letters must be considered from the outset in order not to
> be forced into haphazard mappings for left-overs. In fact I
> think that I in BPJ2 have found reasonable mappings for all
> the letter forms sanctioned by QM save one: half-d (#4.5)
> and {R} were simply the odd men out, but even for them I
> was able to find an albeit far-fetched memory cue, namely
> that American /d/ (and /t/, which usually is merged with
> /d/ in this position: _good at, get it_) between vowels
> sounds like a kind of _r_ to speakers of some accents of
> English and many foreign languages. In old British movies
> even RP speakers can be heard using a sound of this kind
> for the /r/ in words like _very, worry, carry_. This is not
> to say that BPJ2 is the only possible alternative if one
> wants to find satisfactory mappings for the half- letters
> -- it clearly isn't --, but only to say that the mappings
> for the half-letters would have been much more random, and
> hence unsatisfactory, if they had not been considered from
> the outset.
>
> I would really like to hear what native speakers think of
> the mapping of #14 to {J}. All cases of TO _j_ (or _g_)
> corrsponding to #14, and all words where there is variation
> between the sounds of #14 and #16, are recent French loans,
> but {Z} for half-z and {J} for #14 is much better than the
> other way around, since half-z is possibly the most used half-
> letter. The question is hopefully not *if* {J} for #14 is
> acceptable for native speakers/writers -- it ought to be at
> least as acceptable as {I} for #27 and {E} for #29, which
> have to be memory-cued with the foreignisms "Igor" and
> "Etude" respectively --, but rather *how* acceptable it is.
> To my Swedish ear #14 and #16 are the French and English
> sound of _j_ respectively, both sounds being foreign to my
> native language.
>
> It has of course been observed by spelling reformers that
> the functional load of #14 is very low in English, so that
> it might be merged with either #13 or #16, and in that vein
> it might either form a pair with #13 and be mapped to {Z},
> or form a pair with #16 and be mapped to {J}. Read obviously
> saw the sounds of #14 and #16 as related, since he gave them
> letters which were related in shape, but #12 is arguably
> also a related letter-shape for a related sound -- indeed
> #11-16 are a triplet of pairs of related letter-shapes for
> related forms. I'd say the resemblance between #14 and #16
> is greater than between #14 and #12, but then again #13 is
> also closer to #15 than to #11, and I don't think anybody
> would seriously consider mapping #13 to {C}!
>
> The attractiveness of mapping half-z to {Z} is and remains
> the strongest argument in favor of mapping #14 to {J}, but I
> think it is strong enough. I realize that {J} is hardly the
> native speaker/writer's first choice for #14, but at least
> Read's letter-name _J'ai_ will still work!
>
>
> > To start off discussion, I'd like to see if we can move
> > our proposals closer together over the next couple of
> > weeks. Some of the assignments are fairly independent of
> > the rest. I'd like to start with the assignments for #21
> > and alternate #23. I find your suggestion of using G for
> > #21 and N for alternate #21 to greatly improve
> > readability. I think these assignments could be adopted in
> > the other proposals with few, if any, negative
> > ramifications. Peter, Moira, what do you think?
>
> I'm willing to move BPJ2 in line with QS-Nu WRT alt #36 and
> #15, although I don't have the spare time to update my
> documentation ATM.
>
>
> > Also, how much interest is there in following the
> > precedent of the Jerome mapping? If there is not, then
> > perhaps you and I could withdraw BPJ1 and QS-Up. That
> > would simplify things. What do you think?
>
> I'm definitely willing to withdraw BPJ1. For all the Vulcan
> logic of BPJ1, BPJ2 is frankly much better.
>
>
> > If anyone out there is strongly attached to the Jerome
> > mapping, please speak up!
>
> I would also like to hear what other people, who aren't
> proponents themselves, think of the various proposals, ad
> the whole QS-ASCII issue. How many care about it at all?
> If the only ones engaged are the proponents themselves
> there is not much use in spilling any further time and
> bandwidth on this.
>
> Ideally we'll be using whatever QS-ASCII transliteration we
> select only until we get a Unicode mapping for QS. After
> that we will still need keyboard drivers mapping Unicode QS
> letters to the Latin letters on the keyboard as an input
> device, but then there will be nothing to stop people from
> using different keyboard drivers with different mappings
> according to their preference, even making their own drivers
> -- there are free graphical interface programs to help with
> it --, although a collection of downloadable drivers will of
> course be a Good Thing. In practice, however there will
> always be situations when we are not at our own computer,
> and for those situations a standardized transliteration will
> still be desirable for a long time to come. The case with
> phonetic transcription is illustrating: the International
> Phonetic Alphabet has been around in Unicode for some years,
> but people still use ASCII transcriptions like SAMPA and
> others derived from it simply because they are easier to
> type, and there still are mail clients and text editors
> which can't handle Unicode. It is telling that there even
> are programs for converting back and forth between these
> ASCII schemes and Unicode phonetic characters, as well as
> for converting between different ASCII schemes. Such a
> converter -- even an online one -- between Unicode QS and
> different QS-ASCII schemes would be entirely feasible, but
> an improved 7-bit font standard until we get a Unicode
> standard is still desirable.
>
> /BP 8^)>
